articles.headline: G.M. Cuts Production for Quarter
articles.snippet: General Motors cut its fourth-quarter production schedule by 10 percent as a tightening credit market caused sales at other major automakers to decline in August.
articles.abstract: General Motors cut its fourth-quarter production schedule by 10 percent as a tightening credit market caused sales at other major automakers to decline in August.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Sept. 4 — General Motors cut its fourth-quarter production schedule by 10 percent on Tuesday as a tightening credit market caused sales at the Ford Motor Company, Chrysler and even Toyota to decline in August.

articles.headline: The School Cafeteria, on a Diet
articles.snippet: School districts across the country have been taking steps to make food in schools healthier, but some parents say they are taking it too far.
articles.abstract: School districts across the country have been taking steps to make food in schools healthier, but some parents say they are taking it too far.
articles.lead_paragraph: As students return to school this week, some are finding unusual entries on the list of class rules: fewer fried foods, smaller servings and no cupcakes.

articles.headline: Hard Times Help Leaders in Iran Tighten Grip
articles.snippet: Iran’s increasing economic and political isolation is helping leaders to hold back what they see as corrupting foreign influences.
articles.abstract: Iran’s increasing economic and political isolation is helping leaders to hold back what they see as corrupting foreign influences.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN, Sept. 4 — Rents are soaring, inflation hovers around 17 percent, and 10 million Iranians live below the poverty line. The police said they shut 20 barbershops for men in Tehran last week because they offered inappropriate hairstyles, and women have been banned from riding bicycles in many places, as a crackdown on social freedoms presses on.

articles.headline: Bush Shifts Terms for Measuring Progress in Iraq
articles.snippet: President Bush is focusing on new American alliances with the tribes that Washington once feared would tear Iraq apart.
articles.abstract: President Bush is focusing on new American alliances with the tribes that Washington once feared would tear Iraq apart.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 — With the Democratic-led Congress poised to measure progress in Iraq by focusing on the central government’s failure to perform, President Bush is proposing a new gauge, by focusing on new American alliances with the tribes and local groups that Washington once feared would tear the country apart.

articles.headline: No More Privies, So Hikers Add a Carry-Along
articles.snippet: More park stewards in the West are removing outhouses from trails and asking hikers to pack out their own waste.
articles.abstract: More park stewards in the West are removing outhouses from trails and asking hikers to pack out their own waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUMMIT OF MOUNT WHITNEY, Calif., Aug. 29 — The highest outhouse in the continental United States is no more.

articles.headline: Short on Labor, Farmers in U.S. Shift to Mexico
articles.snippet: Concerned about a crackdown on immigrant labor, more farmers have been moving across the border to Mexico.
articles.abstract: Concerned about a crackdown on immigrant labor, more farmers have been moving across the border to Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: CELAYA, Mexico — Steve Scaroni, a farmer from California, looked across a luxuriant field of lettuce here in central Mexico and liked what he saw: full-strength crews of Mexican farm workers with no immigration problems.

articles.headline: For Airlines, Hands-On Air Traffic Control
articles.snippet: Some airlines have taken the initiative to use satellite navigation and other tools to help smooth out an air traffic system that is plagued by delays.
articles.abstract: Some airlines have taken the initiative to use satellite navigation and other tools to help smooth out an air traffic system that is plagued by delays.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 — At Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, Delta Air Lines said its jets take off an average of 10 minutes after pushing back from the gate — three minutes faster than in previous years.

articles.headline: In Turmoil of ’68, Clinton Found a New Voice
articles.snippet: As the nation boiled over Vietnam and civil rights, Hillary Rodham was completing a sweeping political shift.
articles.abstract: As the nation boiled over Vietnam and civil rights, Hillary Rodham was completing a sweeping political shift.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 — In September 1968, Hillary Diane Rodham, role model and student government president, was addressing Wellesley College freshmen girls — back when they were still called “girls” — about methods of protest. It was a hot topic in that overheated year of what she termed “confrontation politics from Chicago to Czechoslovakia.”

articles.headline: China Steps Up Efforts to Cleanse Reputation
articles.snippet: Even as it cracks down on product safety and substandard goods, China lashes out at critics of its exports.
articles.abstract: Even as it cracks down on product safety and substandard goods, China lashes out at critics of its exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, Sept. 4 — In recent weeks, Beijing has begun its most concerted global public relations offensive since the outbreak of SARS, the severe acute respiratory syndrome.

articles.headline: What Is John Dingell Really Up To?
articles.snippet: Long a Congressional ally of the American automobile industry, John Dingell is now promising to introduce a bill that would create a tax on carbon emissions. But is he sincere?
articles.abstract: Long a Congressional ally of the American automobile industry, John Dingell is now promising to introduce a bill that would create a tax on carbon emissions. But is he sincere?
